ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

UNIVERSAL PROCESSING CENTRES
(Setting up)


    The following Question stood in the name of Mdm Ho Geok Choo -

    1. To ask the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance (a) has the Government any plan to set up universal processing centres (UPCs), and if so, how does it intend to expedite this set-up; and (b) how can the Singapore UPCs be distinguished from the competition from Australia, China and India.

    Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan (Hong Kah): Question No. 1, Sir.

    The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance (Mr Lee Hsien Loong): Mr Speaker, Sir, Singapore has made significant headway in positioning itself as the regional IT and financial hub. Institutional investors and analysts have rated highly our national IT infrastructure, quality of manpower, as well as our political and regulatory environment. More companies and financial institutions are outsourcing processing activities, as they seek to save costs and focus on core competencies. The industry has recommended to the ERC setting up Universal Processing Centres (UPCs) in Singapore to leverage our strengths and to support our efforts to develop front, middle and back office activities here.

    The Government supports in principle the set-up of UPCs. The hubbing of higher value-added processing activities in Singapore will create jobs, and generate spin-offs to other economic sectors, such as business advisory, IT and telecommunications. Global corporations and financial institutions are among the early adopters who have consolidated processing along business functions, and also centralised processing either globally or regionally in the American, European or Asian time-zones.

Column: 1068



    Singapore is well-placed to become a key processing hub in Asia. Cost is only one factor. For example, a consultancy study showed that Singapore was a viable location for treasury processing activities despite keen regional competition. Global financial institutions like Citibank and Deutsche Bank already have established processing centres in Singapore serving Asia, and for specific business segments, beyond Asia. We have a critical mass of MNCs and financial institutions here, which is one of our key advantages. The MAS and other agencies are currently in discussion with industry to see how to encourage more UPCs to be set up here.

Column: 1068

UNDER-AGED DRINKING


    2. Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance (a) how many have been caught for under-aged drinking at pubs, discos and at the premises of other licensed liquor sellers for each of the last three years; and (b) what action has been taken by the police to deter such incidents.

    Mr Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, prior to 1st October 2002, which is today, the responsibility for liquor licensing came under the Customs and Excise Department, or CED. As it is primarily a law and order issue, this function has been transferred to the Ministry of Home Affairs with effect from today. Nevertheless, this question has not been transferred and I will take this question.

    35 under-aged persons were caught in 1999, 19 in 2000, and 7 in 2001. In 2002, 20 under-aged persons have been caught so far. Offenders were fined $100 and their parents were informed of the offence.

    The licensees who were caught allowing consumption of liquors by under-aged persons in their premises were fined $300 for the first offence and $500 for subsequent offences.

    CED had been conducting regular checks on licensed premises. Police, in its checks on public entertainment premises,

Column: 1069

had also referred offenders of the liquors licensing regulations to CED for follow-up actions.

    In addition, the Liquors Licensing Board would require licensees who repeatedly infringe the licensing conditions to appear for a hearing before the Board to see whether their licences should be revoked.

    I would like to assure Dr Khor that under-aged drinking is not prevalent. Measures are already in place to ensure that liquors are not sold to under-aged persons. With this function transferred to the Ministry of Home Affairs, I trust that the synergy that would be reaped by the Home Team would keep this problem under control even better.

    Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan: Sir, it was recently reported in the newspaper that there were some private parties held by predominantly junior college students where under-aged drinking might exist. I am not sure whether it is appropriate to ask the Minister if the Police has taken any action on such incidents.

    Mr Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, if there are such cases reported, we will investigate them, but if they are private parties and not in pubs, discos or licensed liquor sellers, it is in somebody's home, it is really the parents' responsibility.

    Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan: Clarification, Sir. When I said "private parties" it was reported to have been held at discos.

    Mr Lee Hsien Loong: Let us have the particulars and we will investigate the matter.

Column: 1069

PUBLIC SECTOR HOSPITALS
(Fee increases)


    3. Dr Lily Neo asked the Minister for Health whether his Ministry will take steps to (i) ease the burden of patients who are affected by the increase in hospital charges; and (ii) implement health-cost

Column: 1070

saving measures to minimise future increase in hospital charges.

    4. Mr Low Thia Khiang asked the Minister for Health what is the estimated amount of revenue the public sector hospitals projected to recover from the recent increases in charges for B2 and C class wards.

    5. Mr Low Thia Khiang asked the Minister for Health whether all restructured hospitals are running efficiently and have fulfilled the original objective of the Government.

    6. Mr Low Thia Khiang asked the Minister for Health when can Singaporeans expect the next round of "regular but small" medical fee hike.

    7. Mr Chiam See Tong asked the Minister for Health whether he will postpone the implementation of the recently announced increases in hospital charges in view of the current economic situation in Singapore.

    8. Mr Gan Kim Yong asked the Minister for Health whether his Ministry will provide a comparison of the operating costs between our hospitals and those of other countries providing similar standards of healthcare services.

    9. Dr Mohamad Maliki bin Osman asked the Minister for Health (a) whether there is an increasing trend since 1997 of Singaporean patients (excluding those who are eligible for Medifund) who have sought help in settling their bills from public hospitals; (b) will the recent increase in hospital charges contribute to this trend; and (c) what measures are being taken to further assist this group of Singaporeans.

    The Minister of State for Health (Dr Balaji Sadasivan) (for the Minister for Health): Mr Speaker, Sir, Question Nos. 3 to 9 are on the same topic, ie, healthcare increases in hospital charges.

    Mr Speaker: So you would like to take them together?

Column: 1071



    Dr Balaji Sadasivan: Yes, Sir. The main responsibility of our public sector hospitals and institutions is to provide Singaporeans, especially the middle and lower income groups, good and affordable healthcare that is appropriate to needs. In this respect, our public sector hospitals have done well and Singaporeans have over the years grown to expect to be treated by competent staff using the latest procedures, drugs and equipment in our public sector hospitals.

    To continue to provide quality healthcare, public sector hospitals must be responsive to medical advances, demographic changes and also able to retain good staff by offering competitive remuneration. These initiatives would, however, inevitably increase their operating costs.

    MP for Holland-Bukit Panjang GRC had asked for a comparison of the operating cost of our hospitals with those of other countries. Unfortunately, such data is not readily available or comparable as hospitals may differ in their accounting treatment, size and casemix. If we, however, consider total healthcare expenditure, Singapore as a whole spends only 3% of its GDP on healthcare when other developed countries spend 7% or more. Our total expenditure on health per capita for 2000 was S$1,500. This is much lower than the per capita expenditure of countries such as United Kingdom (S$3,092), United States (S$8,243) and New Zealand (S$1,890)1. In fact, the World Health Report published in 2000 by the World Health Organisation ranked our health system sixth among 191 countries in overall cost effectiveness. This is a strong indication that our healthcare delivery system provides good value for money to Singaporeans.

    Our two public sector healthcare clusters are not-for-profit entities. As not-for-profit entities, their main objective is not to maximise profits. However, like any other operating entity, public sector


1    Based on exchange rate of 1.78S$ per US$. Our total expenditure on health per capita for 2000 was US$843. Based on OECD Health Data 2002 total health expenditure per capita for 2000 for comparative countries are as follows: United Kingdom (US$1737), United States (US$4631) and New Zealand (US$1062).

Column: 1072

hospitals need to exercise financial prudence and recover cost to ensure their continued viability. Otherwise, over time, standards will decline.

    While Singaporeans will have to pay for the increase in healthcare cost, the Ministry of Health has taken a four-pronged approach to minimise the impact on the public.

    First, by having small, regular fee increases. Restructured hospitals conduct annual reviews of their costs, and review their fees and charges regularly to better reflect their cost profile. In the recent fee revision, the quantum of hospital fee increase has been kept quite small, around $20 for class C wards and $40 for class B2 wards, which most Singaporeans should be able to meet through Medisave. For the hospitals, this translates into an increased total revenue from subsidised patients of around $12 million a year, or 3% of their revenue from subsidised patients.

    Second, by subsidising healthcare for the middle and lower income Singaporeans. MOH has put in place target subsidies for the different ward classes and services. For example, inpatients are subsidised 80% for C and 65% for B2 class wards. The subsidy rate for day surgery is 65% while the subsidy rate for SOC is 50%. Our figures show that MOH has more than met its target obligations. For example, in FY 01, MOH's subvention was 80.5% and 69% of the total C class and B2 class charges respectively.

    Singaporeans pay only for the services that they use. The Government provides additional subvention to the hospitals for teaching, training and research activities. Full Government funding is also provided for building or upgrading hospitals.

    On the part of Singaporeans, they should choose their ward class wisely according to their financial means. To help Singaporeans make that choice, financial

Column: 1073

counselling services are mandatory at all hospitals. My Ministry has also produced a brochure "Ten Tips to Stretch Your Health Dollar" to help lower income Singaporeans access the heavily subsidised healthcare services in the public healthcare system.

    Third, by helping Singaporeans to save for their healthcare needs through Medisave. Several concerns have been raised about the timing of the fee revisions and whether the implementation can be postponed. As the last fee revision was in February 2001, the current fee revision has already been postponed by at least six months. Singaporeans must, however, also understand that the approach to paying their share of healthcare costs must be through long term savings, complemented by appropriate medical insurance plans. This is why we have put in place Medisave, which helps Singaporeans build up a sufficient sum of money over many years to fund their healthcare expenses in the future. Singaporeans can also use their Medisave to pay their MediShield premiums, which will help to further defray their healthcare expenses especially if they suffer serious/catastrophic illness. For subsidised patients, 70% of C and B2 Class bills are entirely met using a combination of Medisave and MediShield, with zero out-of-pocket payment needed.

    Fourth, by providing a safety net. Singaporeans who still cannot afford to pay the highly subsidised rates even after using their Medisave and MediShield can apply for Medifund. Medical Social Workers in the hospitals are also given the flexibility to extend Medifund assistance to those who need help. So far, the approval rate of Medifund applications has consistently remained above 99%. With Government subsidies, the 3M financing framework (Medisave, MediShield and Medifund), is able to pay for 97% of the total charges for B2 and C class patients. Therefore, my Ministry believes that the small fee increases are manageable for the majority of Singaporeans.

Column: 1074



    MP for Jalan Besar and MP for Hougang have asked if our hospitals can be run more efficiently. The answer is: Yes. There is always room for improvement. Public sector hospitals must be managed efficiently and cost containment should become part of the hospital management culture, both among administrators and clinicians. My Ministry has restructured our public sector hospitals to give them more autonomy so that they are more responsive to the market and therefore achieve better cost control and productivity.

    Our hospitals have introduced numerous initiatives, both big and small, to improve their productivity and manage their cost. These include bulk purchasing of drugs, improving process flows such as offering same day admission for surgery. The clusters have also obtained significant savings by outsourcing of services such as catering and promoting greater energy efficiency as well as getting their staff to multitask. The hospitals have also introduced innovative measures to lower their overheads. For example, SNEC has sought to improve utilisation and reduce fixed overheads through marketing excess OT facilities/consultation rooms to non-SNEC Ophthalmologists. All these measures have saved both clusters several million dollars each year.

    Singaporeans must, however, also be realistic as to the extent to which hospitals can keep cost down while continuing to maintain healthcare standards. If Singaporeans expect the best treatment and diagnostics, short queues and good services, they must be prepared to pay for it.

    While we try our best to control cost, it is inevitable that cost will increase each year. Even in the prevailing economic situation, based on MOM data, basic wages showed an average increase of 2.9% for all employees in 2001. Taking into account the 4 percentage points restoration in employer's CPF contribution, the change in overall wage costs (comprising staff remuneration and employer's CPF contribution) amounted to 5.2% in 2001. Drug costs will also continue to increase.

Column: 1075

The average growth rate in prescription only medicine in Singapore from 1997 to 2000 was nearly 8%. In comparison, the projected drug price inflation of the US healthcare system is even higher at 10%.

    Nevertheless, I would like to give my assurance that the Ministry of Health is and will continue to work with public sector hospitals to minimise the cost increases to Singaporeans. I would also like to assure Singaporeans that no Singaporean will be denied essential medical care because of his inability to pay.

    Dr Lily Neo (Jalan Besar): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I object to being referred to as Jalan "Bazaar" GRC MP. I am Jalan Besar GRC MP.

    May I ask the Minister of State whether the hospital fee increase could have been avoided this time, since it has been announced that the hospital fee increase is small? Therefore, can the Ministry of Health not give more subvention to the public hospitals instead, in view of this economic downturn?

    Dr Balaji Sadasivan: Mr Speaker, Sir, running hospitals efficiently and ensuring that all Singaporeans can afford their healthcare are two related but separate issues. Hospitals are most efficiently run if they follow cost recovery principle, that all aspects of health services are costed correctly and resources are allocated appropriately.

    As demand shifts due to advances in medicine, due to shifts in demography, hospitals reallocate their resources to meet these demands. If you have a system that does not respond to these changes continuously, then you will find demand will build up, queues will form, and people have to wait long periods before they get their services. This is what happened in UK with the NHS. The NHS in UK does not follow this principle of cost recovery. And as a result, over the years, the development of services and facilities has suffered, and now patients sometimes have to wait over a year before they can get their surgery. It has reached a crisis

Column: 1076

level that in the UK, they are sending patients down to France, Germany and neighbouring countries for their treatment, while they are trying to upgrade their services. If we do not follow the cost recovery principle, we will be going down this road and, one day, may end up having to send our patients to neighbouring countries too.

    On the second issue of ensuring that all Singaporeans can afford to pay for their medical care, we have the safety net. In 1996, the number of applications for Medifund assistance was 55,859. In 2001, it was 157,190. Despite the almost three-fold increase, the approval rate was 99.7%, and 156,780 applications were approved in 2001. A total of $27.23 million was disbursed. This is more than twice the amount disbursed in 1996. So, I think we need to separate the two issues.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): Sir, while I understand the principle of cost recovery, the cost recovered for the recent round of increase for B2 and C class wards is only $12 million. My question is, given the prevailing economic situation, can the Government not, based on cost recovery, provide additional grants of $12 million to the hospitals? Can the Government not afford that, and thereby will avoid the increases and help Singaporeans to tide over the period?

    Dr Balaji Sadasivan: Mr Speaker, Sir, we would like to target our assistance to those who most need it. By targeting our assistance through Medifund, we are targeting these additional funds to help those who cannot afford healthcare.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, does the Minister of State agree that it is not so much targeting those who need assistance? The fact that the increases are concentrated on B2 and C class wards, you are targeting the lower income who cannot afford. So, you are targeting those people who cannot afford the increases.

    Dr Balaji Sadasivan: About 70% of Singaporeans use B2 and C class wards. For the majority of these patients, their Medisave should be able to cover the cost

Column: 1077

even with the 3% increase in charges. Through Medifund, what we are doing is we are using that money to target those people who cannot afford to pay their healthcare bills with their Medisave, whose Medisave has run out, who do not have the money to pay. Whereas if you were to give the money directly, then those who need the money most may not get it.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang: Supplementary question, Sir. Is the Minister of State saying that ---

    Mr Speaker: Mr Low, you have to catch my eye first, before you ask your question.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sorry, Sir.

    Mr Speaker: Dr Michael Lim.

    Dr Michael Lim Chun Leng (Pasir Ris-Punggol): Sir, while we agree that in the long term, healthcare cost will continue to increase, I think what is needed is more transparency and also clearer justification. I would like to ask the Minister of State to perhaps clarify some of these apparent contradictions in the healthcare system.

    For example, he had said that part of the cost increase was due to new drugs, and yet in the same breath, one of the clusters had said that there was 10-15% decrease in the cost of drugs. And we all know that for non-standard drugs, in other words, new drugs that are in the hospitals, usually they are hardly subsidised. I am not sure how new drugs actually result in an increase in the cost of healthcare.

    Secondly, another contradiction is he said that there is financial counselling in hospitals.     The Senior Minister of State for Law (Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    This Bill amends the International Arbitration Act to make it clear that parties to an arbitration in Singapore are free to adopt the arbitration rules of their choice to govern their arbitration, and that their choice of arbitration rules will be respected by Singapore law and be given the fullest effect possible. Examples of arbitration rules are the UNCITRAL Rules, SIAC Rules, ICC Rules and LCIA Rules.

    This Bill's clarification will reaffirm Singapore's position as an attractive venue for arbitration in the region. It also reaffirms Government's intention to do whatever is necessary to create conducive conditions for the conduct of international arbitrations in Singapore.

    The International Arbitration Act was passed in 1995 to adopt the UNCITRAL Model Law on International Commercial Arbitration as part of Singapore's domestic law. The UNCITRAL Model Law is not a set of arbitration rules. It is intended to be the applicable arbitration law or, in lawyers' parlance - the curial

Column: 1108

law or lex arbitri. Like all arbitration laws, the UNCITRAL Model Law does not contain a comprehensive set of procedural rules, but merely sets out a basic procedural framework. The expectation is that parties will supplement this basic procedural framework with arbitration rules of their choice. Parties are also free to choose their own alternative arrangements in most procedural matters. Indeed, one of the key pillars of the UNCITRAL Model Law is the protection of party autonomy.

    In other words, parties to a Singapore arbitration are free to adopt whatever set of arbitration rules they wish. The Model Law is specifically drafted to ensure that parties' wishes are given the fullest effect possible. Sir, this has been the legal position since this House adopted the Model Law as part of Singapore law in 1995, and has always remained so. And this is how both the international and local arbitration communities have always understood the legal position to be.

    However, some uncertainty has arisen as a result of a Singapore High Court case, Dermajaya Properties v Premium Properties, which was decided earlier this year. The correctness of the actual decision in this case is not in dispute. What has caused concern in some quarters was a comment made by the judge in the course of delivering his judgment. He commented that, if parties adopt a set of arbitration rules which contains procedures which are different from those contemplated by the Model Law, then those arbitration rules would be regarded as incompatible with the Model Law and would therefore be entirely excluded. This comment was strictly not necessary in arriving at the actual decision in the case, and therefore did not have the effect of changing the law on the applicability of arbitration rules.

    Nevertheless, my Ministry has received feedback that lawyers in some international law firms had advised their clients that, as a result of the Dermajaya case, the legal position in Singapore is now uncertain. I understand that some of these

Column: 1109

lawyers have also advised their clients to avoid Singapore as a venue for arbitration.

    The Government has therefore decided to set out the legal position in no uncertain terms. The Bill does this by adding a new section 15A to the International Arbitration Act. The first subsection of the new section 15A declares, for the avoidance of doubt, that arbitration rules adopted by parties shall apply and must be given effect to the extent that they are not inconsistent with a mandatory provision of the Act or the Model Law. A mandatory provision is one whereby the Act or Model Law does not permit the parties to derogate from or vary. This therefore reinforces the principle of party autonomy, and makes it clear beyond doubt that no set of arbitration rules ought ever to be regarded as incompatible with the Act or the Model Law.

    The remaining subsections seek to flesh out the concept of inconsistency, by referring to a number of scenarios where there could be doubts as to whether any inconsistency exists. For example, it is clarified in the Bill that there is no inconsistency if the rules provide for something on which the Act or the Model Law is silent or if the Act or the Model Law provides for something on which the rules are silent. There is also no inconsistency if the rules provide for something which is already covered by a non-mandatory provision of the Act or the Model Law.

    To summarise, the general approach is that arbitration rules adopted by the parties will be given full effect. Where there is a conflict between the arbitration rules and the Act or the Model Law, the rules will prevail unless the conflict is with a mandatory provision of the Act or the Model Law.     However, perhaps we could examine whether the level of stress has exceeded the safe dosage. Are Singaporeans suffering from an overdose of stress? We can also look into how we can help Singaporeans better cope with stress. Can we put in some relief valves?

They may have a big bungalow, but they are hardly at home. They hope that in a different world, the cost of living may be lower and they can afford to have lower income. The Approach

    Sir, to address these issues, we need to focus on three aspects, and I would summarise it with three Cs - Committed, Connected and Concerned.

    First, the Committed people. We need to get Singaporeans committed to our cause. We need them to be committed not only to themselves, but to their family, to their community and to their country. Commitment to Singapore goes beyond the property and assets that they have. Many Singaporeans have houses in other countries, Australia, Canada, UK and more recently, China. House ownership is no longer the key to commitment. We need to create in them a sense of ownership not just of the house, but of the nation. Then they will have a sense of responsibility towards the country that they own and from there comes a sense of belonging.

    Second, the Connected people. We spend millions every year building covered linkways to connect all the HDB blocks. We must also build linkways to connect the hearts of Singaporeans. I believe that Singaporeans do have a heart but they need to be linked up. We need to encourage and build stronger relationship among Singaporeans. Very often when a person is contemplating quitting Singapore, the one last thing that ties him back is the relationship he has with his friends and his relatives here. The stronger that sense of relationship, the more determined he will be to stay and fight. This relationship must start at home. A strong family bond will help spur a strong sense of belonging. This sense of belonging will then motivate us to strengthen our community bonding. With this, we can begin to build relationship with the nation and the individuals. There is no short cut. To try to develop a strong sense of nationalism without strong family and community bonding will be an uphill task.

    Third, the Concerned people. We must change the bo-chap attitude of Singaporeans. I believe that most Singaporeans

Column: 1117

do chap. Judging from the heated response from Singaporeans to PM's speech, I think I am right. And I hope I am right. The question is whether we can further encourage this sense of ai-chap. Can we get Singaporeans engaged? Can we get them concerned? Can we get them involved? It is always difficult to walk away from something you have helped to build up.

Proposed Initiatives

    Mr Speaker, Sir, with these three themes in mind, I would like to urge the Government to consider three initiatives:

    Firstly, I would like to urge the Government to review our education policy to give greater emphasis on building a strong character in our children. Education is fundamental in nation building. The learning institutions have a vital role to play in the remaking of Singaporeans. They carry with them the great responsibility of shaping our future generations. In this regard, I would like to make four suggestions.

    One, greater focus on character building in our curriculum. Our strive for excellence in today's knowledge-based economy dictates that our school curriculum has to focus primarily on knowledge and skills, subjects that can equip our children to participate in the new economy, subjects that matter. Our children too will focus on subjects that matter, namely, those that will be tested and scored. Other subjects, such as Hao Gong Min are given much less emphasis. The schools must provide more than just knowledge and skills. It is where our character is moulded and developed during the early days of our lives. It is also where we first derive our values and principles. If we focus only on the hard subjects, we will produce an army of efficient workers, but we will not produce citizens.

    I can still recall the story of Yuefei, which I read during my primary school days. His patriotic and heroic story has

Column: 1118

inspired many, like me, to feel a sense of duty to the nation. Yuefei was born in the year 1103. When he was young, his mother tattooed four words on his back, "jing zhong bao guo", which means "be loyal and repay your country". He later became the general commanding the armies of the Song dynasty. During the 12th century, when China was attacked by invaders from the north, he led the Song armies in defence of his homeland. His attempt to push north and recover all the lost Chinese territory was opposed, however, by a peace party within the capital headed by Minister Qinhui, who believed that further prosecution of the war would be too costly. Qin's faction proved more influential and, in 1141, Yuefei was recalled to the Song court and imprisoned. Later, he was executed, after being framed by Qin. Yuefei's dedication and commitment to his country serve as a model for many Chinese patriots. Many songs and poems written by General Yuefei are still cherished by the Chinese today, and there are even movies made about Yuefei, eg, "shi er jin pai", and I am sure many Singaporeans of my vintage are also familiar with the story of Yuefei.

    Real historical stories like these will inspire readers to develop a sense of patriotism. Yes, it is a story from China, but I am sure we can find similar stories from other places as well. I would like to suggest that some of these should be incorporated into our school curriculum, especially in the language lessons, so that there is no need to add on the load. For example, instead of talking about the Tail of a Squirrel (one of the passages I read in my daughter's Chinese textbook), we can tell stories about Yuefei or about George Washington and his cherry tree. This way, we can help build the character of our students.

    My second suggestion is to introduce activities that encourage teamwork and inculcate a sense of accountability and responsibility in our schools. These can either take the form of sports and games or project work. It is important for our children to learn from young that he is not alone and he cannot work alone. He is part of the team and part of the big picture.

There is a Chinese saying, "xi sheng xiao wo, wan cheng ta wao", which means to sacrifice yourself for the interest of the greater community. These activities will be able to demonstrate that only by making individual sacrifices - be it time, interest or money - can we succeed and, ultimately, all will benefit from it. Through these activities, they can also learn that while others depend on them to do their best, they too depend on others. This interdependence is the beginning of relationship building and community bonding. Let us not underestimate the impact of some of these seemingly simple and childish activities. They leave a long lasting impression on the minds of our young ones.

    Three, develop greater tolerance for failures in our schools. One of the causes of the kiasu syndrome stems from the fact that we have very little tolerance for setbacks and failures. In our competitive system today, it is natural that failures are costly, whether in schools, society or the economy. However, there is again a Chinese saying, "shi bai shi cheng gong zhi mu", ie, failure is the mother of success. If we cannot accept failures, we cannot achieve success. As we develop a gracious society, we must also be mindful to create greater capacity for failures. This way, Singaporeans will be assured of acceptance by the society and the nation, despite their shortcomings, and they do not need to run to another country.

    Our children in schools must be taught to expect failures, and that perseverance will eventually lead to success. I remember when I first went to the UK for my university education, I had great difficulties in handling the laboratory sessions. The instruction sheets given to me had no instructions at all. They merely stated the requirements. It was up to us to figure out what to do. My teammate - another Singaporean - and I tried every other way but could not get the results. Finally, after some four hours and after all the other students had gone home, we figured it out. We did not fail. We merely found a dozen ways that did not work. Our schools should also consider introducing open-ended activities and programmes

Column: 1120

like these that require our children to try and keep trying. This way, we will build a strong character in them that can accept failures of others as well as of their own.

    Four, revamp our National Education Programme. The objectives behind the NEP are good. But if the programme cannot effectively reach out to our children, it could not serve our purpose. I believe that the subject of National Education is a subject of the heart, and it cannot be taught by simply reciting to them our nation's short history. Colourful as it may be, the younger generation may find it hard to relate. Unlike the first and second generation Singaporeans who have lived through the early years of separation from Malaysia and the struggle against communist infiltration, the 3G generation has grown up in relative security and prosperity.

    I believe that to be successful in our National Education effort, we need to take a more practical approach. I would like to suggest that we enhance and expand the Community Involvement Programme for this purpose. If we allow our students to be involved more actively in community and national development, no matter how big or small it is, it will give them a greater sense of ownership. We can even encourage our tertiary institutions to organise groups that discuss and debate about Government policies. This will generate greater awareness and engagement. There are risks no doubt, but the reward of having a committed citizen is well worth the risks.

    The second initiative: I would like to urge the Government to review our social policies to build a home, and not a hotel. A hotel may have 5-star facilities compared to my small apartment, but it is not my home. What makes a home? A home is a place where I have a relationship with my family members, my parents, my spouse and my children. A home is a place where I have some say in how it is run. A home is a haven that I long to return to for safety and security and, when it is threatened, I would not hesitate to defend it with all I have got. I am almost certain that all of us would agree with this

Column: 1121

perception of home. The issue is: how do we make our nation our home? I would like to make three suggestions.

    One, strengthen our family bonding. If we do not feel at home in our own home, we cannot feel at home in our country. Therefore, we must start with strengthening our family ties. In one of my dialogue sessions with my residents, some of them suggested that we need more space and avenues for family outings and activities. Today, one of the most favourite family pastimes is window shopping. This does nothing to strengthen family ties. In fact, it weakens the pocket and creates more stress. We must create more affordable and convenient destinations for families and friends. Some of our attractions, such as the zoo, the bird park, etc, are designed for tourists, and may not be resident or family-friendly. For example, can we make a conscious effort to review the entrance charges to promote family tickets or season tickets? Or we can even have a universal family pass to allow discounted entries to all our attractions the whole year round, so long as they come as a whole family. This way, we will draw them away from all the shops to spend time with each other in wholesome activities.

    Sir, we have a Children's Day, a Youth Day, a Mother's Day and a Father's Day. Maybe, we should have a Family Day where families take centrestage, and make it a public holiday. This will go a long way to reminding Singaporeans of the value of our family.

    Two, strengthen social and community bonding. Yesterday's newspaper quoted Mr Wee Cho Yaw as saying that there is little meaningful interaction among the various racial groups despite the peaceful co-existence for many years. I hope he is wrong. But we must have realistic expectations. The differences in our cultural and religious background are not easy to bridge. It may take several generations before progress becomes apparent. But we must not quit. We must continue to build on social and community bonding.

Column: 1122

We must develop individual's relationship with the community. From my experience, I find it most effective when people work together on certain projects and they develop an esprit de corp as they go through the process. They learn to respect and accept one another. They develop a special bonding among themselves. As community leaders, they can then help to expand this same bonding to other residents. I would like to urge the Government to give more resources and greater mandate to the Inter-Racial Confidence Circles for this purpose.

    The need for social bonding is not just among different races. Even within the same race, there is also a need to strengthen our bonds. When we lived in kampongs in the old days, we were much closer to one another, although we were physically further apart. We need to re-kindle that kampong spirit to re-build the depth of community bonding. Recently, I attended several lantern festivals within our GRC and I was pleasantly surprised by the large turn-out, from different races, not just the Chinese. This is due in no small part to the hard work of the grassroots leaders, and I must also thank our Mayor, Dr Teo Ho Pin, for his support.

    But it leads me to ask the question: what is in it that attracts the people? Perhaps it is more than just the makan and the goodie bags. Some of them simply brought their kids along and joined in the fun. They lit up candles on the pavement, much to the annoyance of the town councils, and they chatted with one another. If we can promote more of these traditional and festive cultural events, it will help foster greater interaction among our residents. Perhaps the Government can consider sponsoring a few major events like these, in order to give them the resources and the recognition.

    Three, let people have some say. There has been much criticism of the Government for failing to take in feedback seriously. I agree that we cannot govern the country based on feedback alone. The Prime Minister's example of seeing a doctor on slimming pills is a good one.

Column: 1123

But I would suggest that Singaporeans' relationship with the nation is not that of a patient consulting his doctor. It is a family affair. Singapore is not my clinic but my home. In the past, whatever my father says goes. Now, whatever I say, my daughters will ask "why?" and my wife will go "why not?", and a debate will ensue. Eventually, my wife or myself will make a decision, but not without painstakingly explaining to my children the rationale for the decision. They may not always be happy with the outcome, but they are usually satisfied that due consideration has been given to their views.

    Similarly, it is important for the Government to explain its decisions carefully and thoroughly to the people to minimise misunderstandings. The recent fare increase is a case in point. While the people accept that cost increases may be inevitable, the communication process can be improved. Singaporeans need to be assured that the Government understands their current difficulties and have factored them into their decisions.

    Communication and mutual understanding is the basic foundation of a closely-knit family and a loving home. I would therefore urge all Government agencies to make the extra effort in obtaining feedback proactively and to take pains to explain tough policies to our people, so that they can feel part of this big family.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, other than education policy and social policy, the third initiative relates to the need to review our economic policy to strike a balance between economic progress and social cohesion. As our economic restructuring progresses, there is a risk that an increasing number of Singaporeans may feel left behind. They either cannot adapt to the new economy or may find it very painful to do so. They feel that they can no longer fit into the family and they have no choice but to quit. Worse, some of them cannot even afford to quit, given the limited resources they have. So even if they have not physically quit from Singapore, they have done so emotionally. This is a real problem that we should not

Column: 1124

ignore. To this, I would like to make three suggestions.

    One, make space for every Singaporean. We must ensure that all Singaporeans have a place in Singapore, not just for the elite, so long as he tries his best and regardless of his achievements. We cannot abandon the meritocracy philosophy as it is the very basis of our existence and success so far. But if we continue to tell our people that there is no free lunch and that they either wake up or lose out, the message we are giving them may be interpreted as telling them to fend for themselves and that we will do whatever it takes to move on. We cannot say that to a family member, even if he is handicapped and, especially, if he is handicapped.

    One day, my 6-year-old daughter came home from a cartoon movie, Lilo and Stitch. She quoted to me a phrase from the show. She said, "Dad, Ohanna means family." Family means nobody gets left behind. As a family, we must give every member a fair chance, fair in relation to each person's ability. If one of them is slower but he has tried his best, we cannot abandon him. We must assure him that there is a place in Singapore for him because this is his home. He may not get the job he wishes but there are always job opportunities for him so long as he tries and is willing to be flexible. So instead of telling our people that there is no free lunch, perhaps we should change the tune and tell them that we will help them to find their lunch. We must tell them that every Singaporean matters, whether you are a taxi driver or an SIA pilot, whether you are a mechanic or a biochemist, whether you are a professional or an entrepreneur - you have a place and a role in Singapore. You can always contribute meaningfully. You matter to us. And in return, Singapore will matter to them.

    Two, create alternative career opportunities. Not all Singaporeans can fit into the main stream. Some of them may not be as good academically but they may be able to excel in other fields, arts, sports, etc. If we can open up new avenues for these

Column: 1125

people to pursue their career development, it would help to demonstrate that we care about them and help persuade them to remain committed to Singapore. I believe the Remaking Singapore Committee is addressing this issue and I eagerly await its report.

    Three, balance economic progress with social progress. As we pursue economic excellence, we must balance it with strengthening of our social fabric. Those doing better must have a sense of responsibility to care for those who may need an extra hand. The Government needs to take the lead. We are rightly concerned that our help may be abused. But those who abuse the system are quitters because they have already quit trying to do the right thing but, thankfully, these are the exceptions. The EDRS, for example, is a meaningful gesture to show that we care. Although there were abuses, to the majority who have benefited from it, it was a huge success. I am not suggesting that we open up a floodgate on our welfare schemes. However, I am suggesting that perhaps we can afford to be more helpful and not deny help to those who really need it simply because we are fearful of abuse by those who may not need it. This may be a fundamental shift from the Government policy today but this is what family is all about, mutual help and support.

Conclusion

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the Motion on stayers and quitters is intended to spark debate in Parliament on issues of Singaporeans' commitment to the country. The process of nation building has no short cut. It will not happen overnight. But it is a crucial issue, particularly at this point in time when Singapore is at the crossroad. PM's speech was a timely reminder that we cannot take this for granted. As we rebuild our economy, we must also build a home, not a hotel. This will take not only the efforts of the Government alone, but the efforts of all Singaporeans, of all the members in the family. Together, we can build a home where Singaporeans have a say in its shape and size, a home where

Column: 1126

Singaporeans have a part in building, a home where Singaporeans have relationships with one another, and a home where Singaporeans will stay to fight and defend. We must build a home that is uniquely Singaporeans' home.

    Question proposed.

    Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong (Tampines): Mr Speaker, Sir, I decided to move this Motion together with the hon. Member, Gan Kim Yong, because I sense increasing frustration among the younger generation with the state of our society, and a feeling of disconnection with the present system.

    Based on the various surveys and my own dialogues with the younger Singaporeans, it is clear to me that there is a profound longing for a new kind of society. A society that will listen to their voices, and respect them as partners in the development of policy. A society that is rooted in a strong sense of national identity and community, and guided by a vision of a renewed society in which all count and none is excluded.

    This sense is reinforced by the recent debate on "stayers" and "quitters" which was sparked off by Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong's National Day Rally speech. Some say that it is a not a new debate. Indeed, as far back as 1967, Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew, then the Prime Minister, had used such terms in his speech at a convocation dinner of the then University of Singapore. His main message to the younger Singaporeans at that time was: "The future is what we make of it."

    Well, that future is now here. We are advanced in social and economic terms. We enjoy peace and relative prosperity. But something is missing. We are not sure who we are and what being a Singapore citizen means. What are we staying and fighting for?

    The terms used - "stayer" and "quitter" - may be the same as those

Column: 1127

used in the late 1960s, but the debate today is not the same.

    In this post-Cold War world and a very rapidly globalising one, politics has become dominated by the more complex questions of identity. We can see this in the rise in ethnic and religious clashes within states, and the revival of global religions in the world. Advanced IT has given ethnic and religious movements new opportunities for spreading their message and the tribal conflicts that they sometimes spawn. Groups which do not benefit from global capitalism seek to retreat to a simpler world, often offered by the ancient religions and traditions.

    With increasing democracy, some ethnic and religious groups are questioning the way their country has constituted itself and what it means to them as its members. We can see this debate being played out in our neighbouring countries as Muslim groups questioned how Islamic their country should be. In that sense, globalisation and increased democracy in this post-Cold War world have given a particularly sharp edge to identity.

    In a world and in a region that have lost the old order, Singaporeans cannot escape the question of what their statehood is made of. This question rings louder as, in a globalised world, countries seem to become increasingly similar in the political and economic sense through the adoption of democracy and a market economy. It is as if the world is shrinking into a giant McDonalds restaurant.

    Mass migration is another aspect of globalisation. People are increasingly mobile and they go where the opportunities are. This interplay of trends forces Singaporeans to ask themselves who they are, where they belong and what makes their country special.

    One Singaporean puts it very simply: "The world is getting more global, so there is nothing that sets Singapore apart from other places." I feel that it is important to paint this complex backdrop during this debate because it is too easy to frame this debate as only a problem with

Column: 1128

soft 3G generation born with a golden spoon in their mouth.

    The problem with such a view is that, other than being simplistic, it renders any soul-searching about national identity as an unearned luxury. The fact is that the attitudes of the younger generation towards the country has changed because the world has changed.

    The question before us is how to strengthen their sense of belonging to Singapore given all the uncertainties and complexities of the present.

    In our Motion, we called for a thorough review of policies and programmes and for "meaningful changes" to be made. I would like to highlight three reviews in three distinct areas.

    First, at a time when our separate ethnic identities are advancing to the fore, we should review our multi-cultural policies and programmes to ensure that greater stress is placed on our common civic identity and our common cultural heritage. Our civic identity refers to a way of life where citizens define themselves and pursue commonly-held goals. It includes fundamental values such as equality of treatment, equality of opportunity, meritocracy and multi-racialism. This is what citizenship in Singapore is about - who we are, how we live together, what type of people we want to become. It defines to what or whom we give our loyalty, how we relate to other citizens. It is a normative concept, and stems from a moral point of view.

    The arrests of the Jemaah Islamiyah members recently highlight how conflicting loyalties and subscribing to a very different moral view of the world can threaten the viability and security of our nation. Yet, at a time when we should be forging common goals as Singaporeans, my feeling is that we seem to be dealing with the Malay community more and more as a separate group, to be led by their Malay/Muslim political leaders. For instance, take the announcement that the Minister-in-charge of Muslim Affairs, Assoc. Prof. Dr Yaacob Ibrahim and his

Column: 1129

team of Malay MPs want to build a community of excellence for the Malay/Muslim community. This is a laudable goal and I am sure Singaporeans of all races and religions would support this. But I would think this is also a national goal, to help each other achieve excellence. Yet, all the discussions on achieving a community of excellence for the Malay/Muslims have not included the other races, as if they are a group apart. Even as a Member of Parliament, I have not been briefed on what this community of excellence for the Malay/Muslim community means, what does it entail, and if my multi-racial grassroots organisations and I can play a role in helping my Malay residents to achieve that.

    There is nothing wrong with setting different goals for the different communities, but I would ask for a more inclusive and multi-racial approach to helping the groups achieve these goals. We must give each group a sense of sharing a full and equal membership in the nation-state and not let anyone feel singled out.

    Sir, there is an overwhelming constituency in this country, especially the younger generation, who would like to see the ideals of multi-racialism and aspirations for racial equality upheld. But as ever with race, such conclusions must be tempered by complexities and contradictions. Progress towards racial harmony is often uneven. Attitudes towards foreign talents provide an example. You can be a Chinese Singaporean and yet still very unhappy if a Chinese athlete from China wins medals for Singapore under a Singapore passport.

    Such kneejerk responses and our less than coherent multi-cultural policies leave new Singapore citizens with no clear vision of the country they have joined. I suspect that this is because we ourselves are not clear about it. In the absence of a compelling, all-embracing vision, parochial and sectarian interests are filling the void.

    This brings me to our common cultural heritage. We are Southeast Asian, and yet

Column: 1130

we do not highlight or inculcate this as a common cultural heritage. We encourage Singaporeans to trace their roots to their ancestral homelands, saying that such Asian traditions anchor their sense of identity. But we are not the same with the Chinese in China and we know it, and the same goes for the other races, like the Indians in India - they are quite different from the Indians in Singapore. We have more in common with our Southeast Asian neighbours than China and India and far-off places that we call ancestral homelands. Just observe Singaporean students abroad. Whatever their race, their instinct is to group with Malaysians and other Southeast Asians when they go out.

    We say that our national language is Malay, yet we put little effort in getting all Singaporeans to learn it and speak it, other than the Malays themselves as their second language.

    We may rationalise that it may be expedient to signal to the world that we are different from the region - after all, some countries in the region are not the best advertisements for secular progress. But national identity is not to be dictated by short-term expediency or to be manufactured just to attract foreign investors.

    It is a question of who we are and our common destiny. And our destiny is in Southeast Asia, whether we like it or not. We might as well embrace it and make the best of it. To deny that is to rob ourselves of the richness of the Southeast Asian culture and heritage. And to allow either the bland, shallow sameness of cosmopolitanism to take over, or the narrow sectarian pressures of ethnic identity to take hold.

    My second suggestion is to review our policy to ensure that our social and political development is not out of step with our economic development. For instance, women have made great strides in Singapore and yet the Government insists in upholding and preserving the patriarchal system, choosing tradition over civic values enshrined in the Constitution and embedded in our national pledge.

Column: 1131



    Despite the commitment to a more just society upholding equality of opportunity, some Government policies seem to cast women in a secondary role, as submissive, passive women whose paramount mission is to fulfil the roles of a wife and mother.

    They could be deprived of an opportunity to become a doctor just because they are women; they could be deprived of equal medical benefits just because they are women.

    A national identity that is based on patriarchy excludes women. Gender equality issues that we raise in this House repeatedly should not be treated as separate "women's issues", as they tend to be in this House. These are structural questions which confront society in general.

    Another fundamental question is whether Singaporeans feel that they are being treated as citizens in this country, or as consumers of goods and services.

    Since independence, Singapore has implemented rapid economic reforms, which brought us great progress. But the pace of economic reform is often out of step with our social and political development. This has profound consequences for the notion of citizenship. The language of the economy places strong emphasis on the individual - mainly as the consumer of goods and services - and it is often an individual divorced from the wider social and political context. You do not feel rooted if the country only appeals to your salary packet and your pocket.

    Many Singaporeans have expressed the hope for a less stressful society, as Mr Gan has pointed out. The stress factors often cited include the rising cost of living, and a pressuring education system. Rather than dismiss such concerns or defend the status quo, I would urge the Government to conduct a transparent and open-minded study on these issues and see how these concerns can be eased.

    Revive the Cost Review Committee, if need be. Of late, the Government agencies

Column: 1132

have been justifying some price rises by saying, well, prices have to go up because Singaporeans want a higher standard of living and Singaporeans just have to learn how to pay for the higher quality of services that they want.

    Such arguments treat Singaporeans like consumers with endless wants, while they have been trying to respond as citizens wanting to have a say in the pace of change at this difficult time.

    There is a disconnect. Their increasing frustration with the system arises from a sense of impotence, a lack of control over the future. A consequence is the increasing clamour for political reform which we have been hearing, such as that put forward by the Political Matters and Media Group of the Feedback Unit.

    Such ideas are worth engaging and exploring with respect, not because these are all good ideas, but because they reflect the emerging debate about citizenship. They reinforce the recurrent theme, that Singaporeans must now learn to take responsibility for their own destiny - and mistakes - and overcome the tendency to blame others. The strong desire for a better society and community is constantly linked with the need for greater participation and partnership in power.

    This leads me to my third suggestion, which is to review our National Education programme, a suggestion also made by Mr Gan. I feel that we must take urgent steps to prepare individuals to participate as active and responsible citizens in a democracy. For this, we should consider introducing citizenship education as part of our National Education curriculum.

    In Britain, it produced the Crick Report on Citizenship Education in 1998 and, as a result, the subject has formed part of the core curriculum from this year. The aim of the new subject in the UK is to produce active and responsible citizens, aware of their rights and responsibilities.

    In Singapore, I think it is a rare student who knows clearly the role of Parliament and the role of the President. Our students

Column: 1133

need to learn more about the political system in Singapore, how it works, how it has evolved over the years, how that relates to the citizens and their rights and responsibilities as citizens. They need to learn that Parliament is indeed the highest policy-making body in the land. Sometimes, when I look and see students up there (points to students in the public gallery), I wonder what they go back and tell their parents, whether they say, "Really, Parliament is where policies are made." But I fear that some people are beginning to question that.

Because family is the place where their hearts are anchored. So the feeling for their family, the love for their family will be broadened into the love for the nation, and hence become another reason to stay. A friend of mine told her friend's family story. This is a rather typical family with a father, a mother, a brother and a sister. The sister went overseas for studies, married to a foreigner and settled down in that country. She told her brother, "There are plenty of opportunities here. Why don't you come here?" After some persuasion, the brother left Singapore and went to join his sister in that country. He persuaded his girlfriend to go along. They got married, and settled down there. Then, after some time, they invited the father and mother to join them. The parents were initially not willing to go but since two of their children were there, they went. Sounds like a sad story for the stayers? Not really. A few years later, the mother passed away. The father felt lonely and bored in a foreign land because his friends and relatives were in Singapore. So father came back to Singapore. As the brother missed his father, and his wife missed her parents and friends too, they decided to move back to Singapore too. Their feelings for Singapore are even stronger than before. So it does not matter where your physical presence is, so long as your heart is with Singapore, one day you will return. Family and friendship are major pull factors for the stayers.

Column: 1169



    Hence MCDS has set up a 'Family Matters Singapore' Committee to continue to work towards encouraging people to set up families and strengthen their families. This is an arduous task, but it is a task that must be undertaken.

    Lastly, we have to consider or give emphasis to patriotism in our Moral Education Programme. Of course, we hope our nation will never be plunged into serious national crisis, but there are a lot of stories and legends in history that show that one's true commitment will be reflected only in dire adversity. This can help inculcate patriotism in our people.

    I remember that when I was in secondary school, there was this chapter called "The Young Patriot" in our Chinese textbook. It was about a poor Italian boy who was a beggar on board a ship. One day, he came across a group of tourists from England, France and some European countries who gave him some money. These people gossiped about the places they visited. They started to criticise all the bad things about Italy: that it was dirty, full of pickpockets, etc. Suddenly a few coins rained on them. They turned and saw the Italian boy staring hard at them and shouted, "You insulted my country. I do not want your stinking money!" This story has touched me, even today. There are many other stories that I read when I was studying, like "The Drummer Boy" and "The Last Lesson" aimed at inculcating patriotism and national pride in our young hearts. I hope our students today continue to read these stories which would do them a lot of good.

    The problem we are addressing is not third generation Singaporeans being labelled "quitters" or "stayers". It is how to improve from 95 marks to 100 marks. Our challenge is how to retain the stay instinct of an agricultural society like Eritrea, yet be aggressive and successful in globalisation. If we can always remember falling leaves returning to the roots, and always have our hearts in Singapore while we globalise, I believe

Column: 1170

Singapore will thrive and flourish for many generations to come.

    I support this Motion.

    Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, it would seem that Singaporeans from all walks of life have been up in arms at various points over the last nine months about many issues.     As Straits Times' journalist Ong Soh Chin puts it "while stayers and quitters were making their arguments heard, the real revolution was not the issue at hand, but the fact that such debate was being aired publicly" and, I would add, so robustly. Column: 1171

lost for our 3G Singaporeans. One byproduct is the creation of a class of mobile world citizens, who are equally at home in Oslo as they might in Osaka. They are the able and the talented ones who are sought after by nations and peoples for the value creating power they wield - in industry, in entertainment, in technology and in the arts. Think of child prodigy musicians, like Siow Lee Chin, entertainer Kit Chan, or top business brains, like McKinsey's Asia Chief Hsieh Tsun Yan. Interestingly, many of these are now returning home, if not physically, then at least in connectedness, and making a contribution from New York, London, Taiwan or elsewhere.

    As the world, including Singapore, embraces globalisation and geographical and economic boundaries blur, more global citizens would emerge and the distinction between stayers and quitters would get even fuzzier. Besides, as many have already alluded to, one could feel and behave like a stayer or quitter at different points in time, depending on the circumstances. Take myself, for instance. I had studied and worked in the US for two years. At the end of two years, I had thought seriously of continuing my stay in the US, at least for some time, in view of the opportunities available as well as the different lifestyle offered. One might say that I was then contemplating to quit on Singapore. In the end, family ties, my husband's desire to return and the fact that, in the US, one could, as Jack Neo puts it, only be the second wife, brought me back to Singapore.

    Many globally mobile Singaporeans (GMS), as DPM Lee calls them, will still

Column: 1172

feel a sense of belonging to their country of origin, but their inner unction is to a larger calling. This is inevitable. We need to come to terms with the aspirations of such people in a global village. For them, we should give our blessing, because so long as they carry a bit of Singapore in their heart, they will remain our ambassadors and bring Singapore to the world, even as we consciously bring the world to Singapore in our quest for global talent to our shores.

    As noted by SM Lee, in this age of mass travel and migration, Singapore, like other countries, would inevitably lose some of its own talent. However, we must retain a hard core of dedicated Singaporeans sufficient to form the cornerstone of our society. Then we can afford some attrition. Ultimately, enough must stay at any point in time to look after the place, to create prosperity.

    Sir, I think therein lies the heart of PM Goh's remarks addressed particularly to a younger generation of globally mobile Singaporeans, challenging them to make Singaporeans tick as their forefathers before them have done, rather than as an issue of labelling which the hon. Member, Mr Low Thia Khiang, seems to have simplistically assumed.

    The second cause of rootlessness is of greater importance and concern. Dissonance between the Government and its citizens, arising from disenchantment on a host of issues that touches them. Sir, I believe that few people actually quit Singapore for ideological reasons, bar political dissidents, conscientious objectors, and those who are up to mischief, but they form a small minority. From what I observe, people quit because of frustration and/or a sense of betrayal on specific issues that touch them and often touch them deeply, such as education, or a Singaporean society being too regulated and rigid. There is therefore a great need to reduce this dissonance and create goodwill among citizens in general, not just quitters or would-be quitters.

    Sir, in all fairness, the Government has, by the very act of initiating the Remaking

Column: 1173

Singapore Committee, acknowledged that there is a need to review all policies and programmes and leave no stone unturned in view of the generational change taking place. It has started in the right direction and what is needed now is for the Government to take heed of all that has been said and written with an open mind and a certain resolve and boldness to implement the necessary changes.

    The recommendations of the ERC and the Remaking Singapore Committee must be taken seriously and acted upon, where feasible, to ensure that the young stay emotionally connected with the Government and with Singapore.
