Neither are new, and I suspect there could be robust defence from the Ministers concerned, but as there have been much angst and ill-feelings about them, I feel, Sir, that they deserve yet another airing.

    Firstly, injecting more flexibility into the education system. By most standards, we have undeniably one of the best education systems in the world. Ironically, education also appears to be one of the main stress points that trigger quitting.

    Anecdotal evidence suggests that many Singaporeans have migrated to other countries due to their children's education. A successful pediatrician friend of mine migrated to Australia a few years ago mainly because his four children were all unable to cope with Chinese lessons. Another friend, who was a teacher, migrated to New Zealand, as she wanted her eldest son, who was mildly autistic, to be enrolled in a mainstream school rather than a school for children with special needs.

    Yet another friend, who was already a senior civil servant in Singapore, decided to settle for good in New Zealand after the expiry of her one-year no-pay leave to

Column: 1174

accompany her husband who was there on a one-year job attachment. She said that her two primary school going children had enjoyed studying in New Zealand so much they did not want to come back to school in Singapore. In fact, she claims that her son's myopia had improved tremendously during the one-year stay in New Zealand!

    There have been proposals for a through-train secondary school/JC programme as well as more subject choices at the secondary and JC levels. There have also been calls, particularly by the polytechnic students, for local universities to admit more diploma holders. A fourth university, or at least an off-campus extension university to, among others, allow these polytechnic graduates who meet the grades to enter university, has also been called for and is being studied by the Ministry of Education. Otherwise, many polytechnic graduates leave for overseas universities each year. A few have been known to eventually quit the country as they felt that they were treated as second-class citizens.

    There have also been calls for an arts school, in addition to a sports school, to accommodate the young with different talents and abilities besides academic ability. Pleas have also been made for the education policy of children with special needs to be more aligned to those of mainstream schools, such as having these schools come under the ambit of the Ministry of Education, special education teachers to be on the same salary scale as those in the mainstream schools, and allowing more special needs children to be integrated into mainstream schools.

    These proposals have been largely suggested to give Singaporeans more options, inject more flexibility and compassion into the education system, and nurture creativity and an entrepreneurial spirit among our young.

    Most recently, the ERC's education workgroup's recommendation to lift the restriction on Singaporean students attending international schools here would also help minimise the leakage of

Column: 1175

local students to overseas schools as well as migration due to children's education. As noted by the committee, lifting the restriction on local students would give a second chance to local students who do not do well in the public schools, as they may be able to do better under the international schools' curriculum. This idea appears to have found strong support by parents. As one letter writer to Today puts it, "International schools are a good alternative for the minority of parents who think the national school system is inappropriate for their children. As a progressive society, we should allow and respect such diversity of opinion and personal values."

    Sir, I would like to urge the Ministry of Education to seriously consider these proposals, if it is not already studying them, and to be bold in adopting many of these proposals. I believe that in this way many would-be quitters could be converted, and the fidelity of stayers strengthened.

    Secondly, engaging more Singaporeans. With regard to this point, I would first like to revisit what seems to be the perennial favourite topic - feedback.

    Sir, I had, during the Budget debate in April, noted that a friend of mine had asked, "Where is the feedback to my feedback?" Some months have passed, but it appears that this is still a common refrain amongst many Singaporeans. At a recent feedback session for young Singaporeans, it was reported that the youths had asked, "How much of what they said and felt would be channelled to the Government? To what extent did policy makers take their views into consideration when making decisions? And how could they feel a sense of belonging here if their views did not count?"

    There seems to be a yawning gap between the Government's and the public's perception of the feedback mechanism. This is despite the fact that the Prime Minister had, in his National Day Rally speech, pulled out the example of Chek Jawa, amongst others, to show that the Government does listen to and act

Column: 1176

on feedback. The Prime Minister had also noted that the Government cannot run a country based on feedback alone nor should it bend to every whim and fancy. But, on the flip side, there is a real danger that this perception gap could widen as Singaporeans become more educated and informed, and increasingly demand greater public consultation and voice in policy formulation.

    To close the perception gap and ensure that the feedback mechanism is not viewed as a black hole, the Government could, as far as possible, allow for more pre-policy rather than post-policy feedback. It is noted that the Government is already heading in this direction, as there have been more feedback sought, eg, on the ERC's recommendations, Remaking Singapore, and the review of the JC and secondary school education.

    The Government should also make a conscious effort to identify changes which have been made due largely to feedback received. As Dr Ow Chin Hock recently noted: "Whenever possible, acknowledge the contributions of the feedback providers." This would give people a sense of ownership, that they have made a constructive contribution to policy making. Perhaps, the inclusion of my female, single MPs in Parliament today, as well as the change in policy to allow male civil servants to take child medical sick leave, could be attributed in part to some feedback received in the past.

    However, ultimately, to break the perception deadlock and reduce the dissonance between the Government and its citizens, there will have to be a mindset change by both parties. Otherwise, the perception gap would be a vicious cycle.

    The people say that the Government does not listen, whilst the Government says that it does. We do not like the Government to tell us what to do. Yet, each time we have a crisis, we run to it for solutions. We know that our Government will do its best and, thus, are quite happy to leave it to do the thinking for us. However, if what it does is not to our satisfaction, we have a scapegoat. We grow up

Column: 1177

relying on the Government to think ahead for us, and the Government grew up doing just that, appearing to be more used to giving directives than listening to feedback and, thus, the "Father knows best" perception. It took us 37 years to grow into this mould. Hence, time is needed for both parties to change and adapt to their new roles.

    As noted by Mr Tan Tarn How of the Straits Times, the Government must accept that whilst it may know more, it does not mean that it knows better - if I may add, at least not all the time. The people must also understand that if they want more flexibility, greater freedom, more say and more choices, then they cannot run to the Government for help at the slightest hint of trouble. Will this change of style and tone create more risks for both the Government and the governed? Most certainly it will, but taking risks and getting hurt in the process is the essence of the new economy. Sir, I would venture to say that in this new Internet era, governments do not have a choice but to accept greater messiness in the social and political spheres.

    The second area for engaging the people relates to National Education and bonding. Besides policy changes that could strengthen our 3G Singaporeans' sense of belonging, many of which have already been identified by the ERC and the Remaking Singapore Committee, National Education, where our young are given lessons about Singapore, would help to give them a sense of identity. As the Minister for Education succinctly puts it: "We want them to know the Singapore Story - how Singapore succeeded against the odds".

    Sir, I believe that our schools are the incubators for our future stayers - the citizens who are proud of Singapore. Hence our National Education programme should continue and should be further built upon. The achievements and successes of Singapore and Singaporeans, such as local literature, locally-produced films, successful businessmen

Column: 1178

and businesses, could be compiled for National Education lessons.

    We should also continue to encourage family-based activities to build stronger family units, community activities to foster ties among friends and neighbours, as well as organise more national events that seek to bind all Singaporeans, regardless of race, language and religion. This is especially so in the light of the JI arrests, which have put our Malay/Muslim compatriots under an uncomfortable spotlight.

    In this regard, a national coordinating body could be formed to organise events at the national level for all Singaporeans. One such idea that arose out of my recent IRCC focus group discussion was organising a huge religious "Expo" at the national level. Talks could be given at the "Expo" by various religious leaders to enlighten members of the public about the basic tenets of all major religions practised in Singapore, to promote better understanding.

    At the heart of the whole issue, Sir, is the fundamental question of what it is that connects us to Singapore. It is true that physical location per se does not make a stayer or a quitter. It is more where the heart is that defines the stayer or quitter. But the physical and the tangibles are the symbols that define the boundaries of our heart.

    Sir, in the end, I believe it is the combination of the people - our families and loved ones, friends and emotional bonds of kinship; the place - the sights, sounds and smells of the familiar, and the things that loosely define Singaporean-ness, such as chicken rice and the ubiquitous HDB flats; and, finally, the privilege - our birth rights as citizens and, thus, "first wife" status, as per Jack Neo, that determine our rootedness to the country.

    In recent times, the last factor - privilege - which translates into the opportunity to forge a partnership with the Government in charting Singapore's path, seems to take on more significance among the young. This is evidenced by the young clamouring at feedback

Column: 1179

sessions to be heard and to know what role they can play in policy making. A combination of the ability and means to be more footloose as well as Singapore's uncertain economic future may have led to this.

    Singapore's existence is in many ways a historical accident. We are a nation constrained by limited land and people. Our survival as a nation is thus not a given, and we would always have to create our niche in a global village in order to survive. Hence, Sir, I believe the Government and the people need to pull and work together in order to make the quitters stayers, and the stayers the shapers of our collective destiny.

    In this light, Sir, I support the motion.

the second and third. For the second and third groups, the challenge is how to ensure that the links are maintained even while they are away. WRITTEN ANSWER TO QUESTION
CONSTITUTION OF THE REPUBLIC OF SINGAPORE


    1. Mr Charles Chong asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether his Ministry will review Article 122(1) of the Constitution of the Republic of Singapore making the conditions for according Singapore citizenship by descent to foreign born children of a Singapore parent more gender equal.

    Mr Wong Kan Seng:

    Our Constitution does not make any distinction between a child born in Singapore to either a Singaporean father or Singaporean mother. Such children are Singapore citizens by birth. This would apply to most cases, as the majority of children born to a Singaporean parent or parents, are born in Singapore.

    Our Constitution also provides for children born overseas to at least one Singaporean parent to be granted citizenship. Children born overseas to a Singaporean mother (and foreigner father) are not deprived of a chance to be citizens.

    Article 122(1) of the Constitution allows for citizenship by descent to be granted to a child born overseas to a Singaporean father, provided that the child is registered within one year of birth. If the registration is not done within one year of birth, the Constitution allows for citizenship by registration to be granted to such children.

    Article 124 of the Constitution allows for children born overseas of a Singaporean mother (and foreigner father) to be citizens by registration.

    Although the Constitution has made this differentiation for births overseas, the practical effect is not great. The great majority of applications for citizenship of children born overseas to a Singaporean parent are approved.

    The only other discernible difference between citizenship by descent and citizenship by registration lies in Article 129(3)(b) of the Constitution, which states that the Government may deprive the citizenship of a citizen by registration if, within 5 years of the grant of citizenship by registration, he has been sentenced to imprisonment for a term of more than 1 year or to a fine of more than $5,000 or if he has been engaged in activities which are prejudicial to the security of Singapore, or the maintenance of public order or essential services, or in any criminal activities prejudicial to the interests of public safety, peace or good order. For most people, these conditions are practically not applicable. Thus, while the form of the citizenship differs between a child born overseas to a Singaporean father and mother, the substance is practically the same.

    We are not the only country to make such a distinction. We are guided by the reasoning that, in communities like ours, the man is traditionally the main or in many cases, the sole breadwinner of the family. The man's place of employment would therefore usually decide where the family would reside. It would therefore be more practical for the citizenship of the child born overseas to follow that of the father's.

    Since the substance of the citizenship granted to children born overseas in either case is practically the same, my Ministry is of the view that, for now, we should not amend Article 122(1) of the Constitution.
